Message.Msg: I find the lack of movement in Yahoo share price to be odd. They are still below the price when shareholders reacted to the possibility that Yahoo might do something other than pay out the proceeds. Meanwhile the market has moved up, Alibaba has a tangible higher evaluation, Yahoo Japan has gone higher, etc. Mind you, I would have preferred it if yahoo used the money to reinvent itself and buy new intellectual property, but....still...it should have gone up much more after hours. What are people waiting for now?

Topic.Title: When will yahoo! break out?

Message.Msg: 8/29/12 1:26 PM EDT TAMPA, Fla. -- Yahoo News has fired Washington bureau chief David Chalian after he was caught on a hot-mic during an online video broadcast saying that Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, had no problem with African Americans suffering as a result of Hurricane Isaac, a source familiar with the situation tells POLITICO. (Now confirmed: see below) "They're not concerned at all. They're happy to have a party with black people drowning," Chalian said over a break during the ABC News/Yahoo News webcast, in reference to the fact that the GOP convention in Tampa is taking place as Hurricane Isaac makes landfall on the north Gulf coast. (PHOTOS: 5 crazy convention moments) The conservative media watchdog organization NewsBusters first posted audio of Chalian's remarks, but referred to him as an ABC News employee (and offered slightly inaccurate transcription). ABC News spokesperson Julie Townsend informed the organization that Chalian was with Yahoo.

Message.Title: Buybacks for Underperforming Stocks
Message.Msg: are useless historically. If we spend the $3.6 billion on buybacks, we'll reduce the share by 18%. The analysts, all of who have a "wait and see" attitude on a stock like Yahoo, will simply lower their multiple by 20%. It's very arbitrary for them. That's why so many underperforming stocks, show nothing to the average shareholder, after massive buybacks. Can't believe they would do that, after 3 years of no stock growth. Also, the BOD will issue lots of new free shares to themselves. The rich get richer, and the dumb retail shareholder stays in neutral. #$%$ if this happens.

Topic.Title: Notice HOw They BeatchSlap it DOWN at $16? Shorts Remain FIRMLY in Control!

Message.Msg: Yeah, I noticed.

Topic.Title: $6b in cash

Message.Msg: Yahoo giving you money makes Yahoo lose value = lower share price. You get a dollar and the stock drops a dollar. No free money.

Topic.Title: $6b in cash

Message.Msg: You are using Book Value as your sole measuring stick to determine the stock's price. Stocks (as you know, no preaching) are valued based upon the cumulative future earnings and distributing cash does not necessarily have anything to do with that. It can be argued that a $2-$3 special dividend is simply a catch up for all of the years when a dividend could have been paid but was not. Also, along with the special dividend I expect Yahoo to announce a regular quarterly dividend. Along with a share buy back (which will reduce the cost of the dividend) the share price will not go down (IMHO) by the amount of the special dividend but will in fact go up to reflect the new yield. Managements do in fact manipulate their share price by doing such things but they do work in the market and do enhance shareholder value immediately and over time. .

Topic.Title: $6b in cash

Message.Msg: If you think the stock will NOT go down by the approximate amount of the special dividend, you are either fooling yourself, or you're just plain, old-fashioned Stupid!

Message.Title: $646M from Alibaba deal already spent on buybacks...$3 billion more to spend. How will they do it?
Message.Msg: Yesterday's Yahoo! press release states that Yahoo has already bought back shares totaling $646million (about 41 million shares, +/- a couple million). These shares were acquired with "down payment funds over the past few months (I assume for between $14.70-$16.10). They will return another $3 billion to shareholders in one form or another. Based on the fact that they already started using funds from the sale (the down payment) to buy back shares, I think a substantial chunk of the 3B will be "returned" to share holders in buybacks. It the price of shares goes up then I expect a larger proportion of funds will be allocated as a dividend. So long as it is in the 15s or low 16s, I think they will get more bang for buck in a continuation of the buy-back program. But, this is only a piece of a plan that has not been outlined or defined to current or potential investors, So, even with money in the bank, Yahoo! still appears to be "on hold" From Yahoo release: Yahoo! will return approximately $3.65 billion in after-tax proceeds to shareholders, or 85 percent of the net cash proceeds from the initial sale of its shares in Alibaba. This amount includes $646 million the company has already returned to shareholders through share repurchases since the announcement of the transaction, as well as an additional $3.0 billion. After accretion from the Alibaba share repurchase, Yahoo! continues to own approximately 23 percent of Alibaba Group common stock, valued at $8.1 billion based on this most recent round of funding. Together with its preferred stock, the implied valuation of Yahoo!'s entire remaining stake is approximately $8.9 billion.

Mu advice: sell here (I did at $16 )and buy it back in a few months at $14 1/2.

Topic.Title: Yahoo is a bargain

Message.Msg: $15.86 is the market telling you that your math is flawed. No joke. It just got over $4 billion cash from the Alibaba deal by selling half of its Alibaba stake. And that makes the remaining stake in Alibaba worth the same, 4.2+4.2=8.4 billion. No joke. It's market value is only $19 billion. This means the whole Yahoo business plus its Yahoo Japan are worth over $10 billion. No joke. They will possibly need to sell Yahoo Japan at a discount and China is not the safest place to own part of a company (you can google AliPay). No joke.

Topic.Title: Yahoo is a bargain

Message.Msg: I stand by the remaining stake in Alibaba is worth $9 billion. See Yahoo news release. "After accretion from the Alibaba share repurchase, Yahoo! continues to own approximately 23 percent of Alibaba Group common stock, valued at $8.1 billion based on this most recent round of funding. Together with its preferred stock, the implied valuation of Yahoo!'s entire remaining stake is approximately $8.9 billion."

Message.Title: YHOO Valuation question?
Message.Msg: OK so as a recent investor in YHOO, I am looking at the value side of things. Here are my quick calculations for sum-of-the-parts: 1) Remaining estimated stake in Alibaba = $5.8 billion after tax (almost $9 billion pre-tax as per most recent valuation) 2) Estimated 34% stake in Yahoo! Japan = $3.7 billion after tax (almost $7.3 billion pre-tax per most recent stock market quote) 3) Previous Net cash position after debt = $2 billion (before recent sale of Alibaba stake) 4) Cash from recent sale of Alibaba stake = $4.3 billion Adding all that together gives us a rough valuation of $15.5 billion for these parts, and the rest of the Yahoo! businesses are valued at about $3 billion? These Yahoo! businesses and properties are generating about $1 billion in annual profits, which are flat-lining after decreasing for many years. Does that quick back-of-the-napkin analysis seem correct? Am I missing something?

Topic.Title: Yahoo is a bargain

Message.Msg: The sale was for 19% of Alibaba, reducing stake from 42% to 23%, resulting in $4.2 billion in cash after taxes, plus $800 million in preferred shares. So about $5 billion after taxes, in cash and preferred, for a 19% stake. The remaining 23% should fetch another $5.6 billion after taxes and fees, if not more. I agree with you that the market has been undervaluing Yahoo! for a long time, and for a reason - the market believes that Yahoo! cannot monetize the assets and profitably use the proceeds.

Topic.Title: YHOO Valuation question?

Message.Msg: The value on the remaining stake of alibaba would be too high if you assume it is equal to this most recent sale. Which I'm not saying it is but that provides a benchmark to value the last half of the stake. The value of the yahoo japan stake is too low after tax. The core businesses were last generating $700 million I believe, which has been declining the last 3 or 4 years if I remember correctly. So I'm not saying 3 billion is undervalued for this, but how much would you pay for a business that continually drops in earnings/cash flow. Hoping that Mayer turns this core business around. Yahoo has lots of assets and lots of opportunities to team up with partners. Would like to see them get rid of the non-core assets that have value but aren't making money. This would help show a true core business number and provide extra cash. I am long call options in yahoo.

Topic.Title: YHOO Valuation question?

Message.Msg: Also I wonder if after selling the Yahoo Japan stake and half of Alibaba if that would cause Yahoo's book value to drop below 1. Would be interesting, not that it matters too much. Also, don't listen to all the pumpers on the forums. It is true that hotmodel and drgloom are hated here, but they're the more intelligent of the posters.

Topic.Title: YHOO Valuation question?

Message.Msg: Thank you for your response, I appreciate it. One clarification, why would the rest of Alibaba be valued lower than what they just got? $4.3 billion in cash after taxes plus another $800 million in preferred shares for a 19% slice of Alibaba that they sold off should translate to $5.8 billion in cash (and more preferred shares, if that's the route they take). I mean, the preferred shares will be redeemed eventually, and the tax on the gain has already been paid out of the cash proceeds.

Topic.Title: YHOO Valuation question?

Message.Msg: I wasn't including the set of preferred that yahoo just received into the value of the "2nd half". You are right. There are several graphs floating around with yahoo core earnings while stripping out alibaba and yahoo japan. If you find that that would answer the question you are looking for about the cash flow from the core, can't be too hard to find.

Topic.Title: YHOO Valuation question?

Message.Msg: Indeed, the earnings due to core assets can be derived after looking at the earnings reports and 10k filings. For the last two years core assets have generated $790 million and $560 million in earnings, respectively. In fact, the Yahoo! Japan stake, as per the equity method used, allocates close to $400 million as well. So that stake for Yahoo Japan might fetch a tidy sum if Softbank really wants to own it and they can figure out a way for all parties to come to an agreement.

Topic.Title: Yahoo! Japan Sold Leaves Yahoo Vulnerable

Now they suddenly become a complication hindering a buyout. Seems to me like you make up -facts- as you go along not really having any idea what’s happening around you.
